00017 =head1 NAME
00018 
00019 contextPiecewiseFunction.pl - Allow usage of piecewise functions.
00020 
00021 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00022 
00023 This file implements a context in which piecewise-defined functions
00024 can be specified by students and problem authors.  To use it, add
00025 
00026     loadMacros("contextPiecewiseFunction.pl");
00027 
00028 and then use
00029 
00030     Context("PiecewiseFunction");
00031 
00032 to select the context for piecewise functions.  There are several
00033 ways to produce a piecewise function.  For example:
00034 
00035     $f = Compute("x if x >= 0 else -x");
00036     $f = Compute("x if x >= 0 else -x if x < 0");
00037     $f = Formula("x+1 if x > 2 else 4 if x = 2 else 1-x");
00038     $f = PiecewiseFunction("x^2 if 1 < x <= 2 else 2x+1");
00039     $f = PiecewiseFunction("1 < x <= 2" => "x^2", "2x+1");
00040     $f = PiecewiseFunction("(1,2]" => "x^2", "2x+1");
00041     $f = PiecewiseFunction(Interval("(1,2]") => "x^2", "2x+1");
00042 
00043 You can use either Compute() or Formula() interchangeably to
00044 convert a string containing "if" and "else" to the corresponding
00045 PiecewiseFunction.  The PiecewiseFunction() constructor can
00046 also do this, or you can pass it a list of interval=>formula
00047 pairs that specify the various branches.  If there is an
00048 unpaired final formula, it represents the "otherwise" portion
00049 of the function (the formula to use of the input is not in
00050 any of the given intervals).
00051 
00052 Note that you can use Inveral, Set, or Union objects in place of
00053 the intervals in the specification of a piecewise function.
00054 
00055 The PiecewiseFunction object TeXifies using a LaTeX "cases"
00056 environment, so you can use these objects to produce nice
00057 output even if you are not asking a student to enter one.
00058 For example:
00059 
00060     Context("PiecewiseFunction");
00061     
00062     $f = Formula("1-x if x > 0 else 4 if x = 0 else 1+x if x < 0");
00063     $a = random(-2,2,.1);
00064     
00065     Context()->texStrings;
00066     BEGIN_TEXT
00067     If \[f(x)=$f\] then \(f($a)\) = \{ans_rule(20)\}.
00068     END_TEXT
00069     Context()->normalStrings;
00070     
00071     ANS($f->eval(x=>$a)->cmp);
00072 
00073 Normally when you use a piecewise function at the end of a sentence,
00074 the period is placed at the end of the last case.  Since
00075 
00076     \[ f(x) = $f \].
00077 
00078 would put the period centered at the right-hand side of the function,
00079 this is not what is desired.  To get a period at the end of the last
00080 case, use
00081 
00082     \[ f(x) = \{$f->with(final_period=>1)\} \]
00083 
00084 instead.
00085 
00086 =cut
00087 
00088 loadMacros("MathObjects.pl");
00089 loadMacros("contextInequalities.pl");
00090 
00091 sub _contextPiecewiseFunction_init {PiecewiseFunction::Init()}
00092 
00093 package PiecewiseFunction;
00094 
00095 #
00096 #  Create the needed context and the constructor function
00097 #
00098 sub Init {
00099   my $context = $main::context{PiecewiseFunction} = Parser::Context->getCopy("Inequalities");
00100   $context->{value}{PiecewiseFunction} = 'PiecewiseFunction::Function';
00101   $context->operators->add(
00102      "if " => {
00103         precedence =>.31, associativity => 'left', type => 'binary',
00104         string => ' if ', TeX => '\hbox{ if }', class => 'PiecewiseFunction::BOP::if',
00105      },
00106 
00107      "for " => {
00108         precedence =>.31, associativity => 'left', type => 'binary',
00109         string => ' for ', TeX => '\hbox{ for }', class => 'PiecewiseFunction::BOP::if',
00110      },
00111 
00112      "else" => {
00113         precedence =>.3, associativity => 'right', type => 'binary',
00114         string => " else\n", TeX => '\hbox{ else }', class => 'PiecewiseFunction::BOP::else',
00115      },
00116 
00117      "in " => {
00118         precedence => .35, asscoiativity => 'right', type => 'binary',
00119         string => ' in ', TeX => '\in ', class => 'PiecewiseFunction::BOP::in',
00120      },
00121   );
00122   $context->{value}{InequalityIn} = 'PiecewiseFunction::Interval';
00123   $context->{value}{'Formula()'} = 'PiecewiseFunction::Formula';
00124   $context->{cmpDefaults}{PiecewiseFunction} = {reduceSets => 1, requireParenMatch => 1};
00125 
00126   main::PG_restricted_eval('sub PiecewiseFunction {Value->Package("PiecewiseFunction")->new(@_)}');
00127 }

00132 #
00133 #  A class to implement undefined values (points that
00134 #  are not in the domain of the function)
00135 #
00136 package PiecewiseFunction::undefined;
00137 our @ISA = ('Value');
00138 
00139 sub new {
00140   my $self = shift; my $class = ref($self) || $self;
00141   my $equation = shift;
00142   bless {data => [], isUndefined => 1, equation => $equation}, $class;
00143 }
00144 
00145 sub value {undef}
00146 
00147 sub string {die "undefined value"}
00148 sub TeX    {die "undefined value"}
00149 sub perl   {"PiecewiseFunction::undefined->new()"}

00151 ##################################################
00152 #
00153 #  Implement the "if" operator to specify a branch
00154 #  of the piecewise function.
00155 #
00156 package PiecewiseFunction::BOP::if;
00157 our @ISA = ('Parser::BOP');
00158 
00159 #
00160 #  Only allow inequalities on the right.
00161 #  Mark the object with identifying values
00162 #
00163 sub _check {
00164   my $self = shift;
00165   $self->Error("The condition should be an inequality") unless $self->{rop}{isInequality};
00166   $self->{type} = {%{$self->{lop}->typeRef}};
00167   $self->{isIf} = $self->{canCompute} = 1;
00168   $self->{varName} = $self->{rop}{varName} || ($self->context->variables->names)[0];
00169 }
00170 
00171 #
00172 #  Return the function's value if the variable is within
00173 #    the inequality for this branch (otherwise return
00174 #    and undefined value).
00175 #
00176 sub eval {
00177   my $self = shift;
00178   my $I = $self->{rop}->eval;
00179   return PiecewiseFunction::undefined->new unless $I->contains($self->{equation}{values}{$self->{varName}});
00180   return $self->{lop}->eval;
00181 }
00182 
00183 #
00184 #  Make a piecewise function from this branch
00185 #
00186 sub Compute {
00187   my $self = shift; my $context = shift || $self->context; my $method = shift || "new";
00188   return $context->Package("PiecewiseFunction")->$method($context,$self->flatten($context));
00189 }
00190 
00191 #
00192 #  Make an interval=>formula pair from this item
00193 #
00194 sub flatten {
00195   my $self = shift; my $context = shift || $self->context;
00196   my $I = $self->{rop}->eval;
00197   my $f = $context->Package("Formula")->new($context,$self->{lop});
00198   return ($I => $f);
00199 }

00201 #
00202 #  Print using the TeX method of the PiecewiseFunction object
00203 #
00204 sub TeX {(shift)->Compute(undef,"make")->TeX}
00205 
00206 #
00207 #  Make an if-then-else statement that returns the function's
00208 #    value or an undefined value (depending on whether the
00209 #    variable is in the interval or not).
00210 #
00211 sub perl {
00212   my $self = shift; my $parens = shift;
00213   my $I = $self->{rop}->eval; my $x = "\$".$self->{varName};
00214   my $condition = $I->perl.'->contains('.$x.')';
00215   my $lop = $self->{lop}->perl; my $rop = 'PiecewiseFunction::undefined->new';
00216   return '('.$condition.' ? '.$lop.' : '.$rop.')'
00217 }
00218 
00219 ##################################################
00220 #
00221 #  Implement the "else" operator to join the
00222 #  different branches of the function.
00223 #
00224 package PiecewiseFunction::BOP::else;
00225 our @ISA = ('Parser::BOP');
00226 
00227 #
00228 #  Make sure there is an "if" that goes with this else.
00229 #
00230 sub _check {
00231   my $self = shift;
00232   $self->Error("You must have an 'if' to the left of 'else'") unless $self->{lop}{isIf};
00233   $self->{type} = {%{$self->{lop}->typeRef}};
00234   $self->{isElse} = $self->{canCompute} = 1;
00235 }
00236 
00237 #
00238 #  Use the result of the "if" to decide which value to return.
00239 #
00240 sub eval {
00241   my $self = shift; my $lop = $self->{lop}->eval;
00242   return (ref($lop) eq 'PiecewiseFunction::undefined' ? $self->{rop}->eval : $lop);
00243 }
00244 
00245 #
00246 #  Make a PiecewiseFunction from the (nested) if-then-else values.
00247 #
00248 sub Compute {
00249   my $self = shift; my $context = shift || $self->context; my $method = shift || "new";
00250   return $context->Package("PiecewiseFunction")->$method($context,$self->flatten($context))
00251 }
00252 
00253 #
00254 #  Recursively flatten the if-then-else tree to a list
00255 #  of interval=>formula pairs.
00256 #
00257 sub flatten {
00258   my $self = shift; my $context = shift || $self->context;
00259   my $flatten = $self->{rop}->can("flatten");
00260   return ($self->{lop}->flatten($context),&$flatten($self->{rop},$context)) if $flatten;
00261   my $f = $context->Package("Formula")->new($context,$self->{rop});
00262   return ($self->{lop}->flatten($context),$f);
00263 }
00264 
00265 #
00266 #  Don't do extra parens for nested else's.
00267 #
00268 sub string {
00269   my ($self,$precedence,$showparens,$position,$outerRight) = @_;
00270   my $string; my $bop = $self->{def};
00271   $position = '' unless defined($position);
00272   $showparens = '' unless defined($showparens);
00273   my $addparens = defined($precedence) && ($showparens eq 'all' || $precedence > $bop->{precedence});
00274   $outerRight = !$addparens && ($outerRight || $position eq 'right');
00275 
00276   $string = $self->{lop}->string($bop->{precedence},$bop->{leftparens},'left',$outerRight).
00277             $bop->{string}.
00278             $self->{rop}->string($bop->{precedence});
00279 
00280   $string = $self->addParens($string) if $addparens;
00281   return $string;
00282 }
00283 
00284 #
00285 #  Use the PiecewiseFunction TeX method.
00286 #
00287 sub TeX {(shift)->Compute(undef,"make")->TeX}
00288 
00289 #
00290 #  Use an if-then-else to determine the value to use.
00291 #
00292 sub perl {
00293   my $self = shift; my $parens = shift;
00294   my $I = $self->{lop}{rop}->eval; my $x = "\$".$self->{lop}{varName};
00295   my $condition = $I->perl.'->contains('.$x.')';
00296   my $lop = $self->{lop}{lop}->perl; my $rop = $self->{rop}->perl;
00297   return '('.$condition.' ? '.$lop.' : '.$rop.')';
00298 }

00301 ##################################################
00302 #
00303 #  Implement an "in" operator for "x in (a,b)" as an
00304 #  alternative to inequality notation.
00305 #
00306 package PiecewiseFunction::BOP::in;
00307 our @ISA = ('Parser::BOP');
00308 
00309 #
00310 #  Make sure the variable is to the left and an interval,
00311 #  set, or union is to the right.
00312 #
00313 sub _check {
00314   my $self = shift;
00315   $self->{type} = Value::Type("Interval",2);
00316   $self->{isInequality} = 1;
00317   $self->Error("There should be a variable to the left of '%s'",$self->{bop})
00318     unless $self->{lop}->class eq 'Variable';
00319   $self->Error("There should be a set of numbers to the right of '%s'",$self->{bop})
00320     unless $self->{rop}->isSetOfReals;
00321   $self->{varName} = $self->{lop}{name};
00322   delete $self->{equation}{variables}{$self->{lop}{name}} if $self->{lop}{isNew};
00323   $self->{lop} = Inequalities::DummyVariable->new($self->{equation},$self->{lop}{name},$self->{lop}{ref});
00324 }
00325 
00326 #
00327 #  Call this an Inequality so it will be allowed to the
00328 #  right of "if" operators.
00329 #
00330 sub _eval {
00331   my $self = shift;
00332   bless $self->Package("Inequality")->new($_[1],$self->{varName}),
00333     $self->Package("InequalityIn");
00334 }
00335 
00336 ##################################################
00337 #
00338 #  This implements the "in" operator as in inequality.
00339 #  We inherit all the inequality methods, and simply
00340 #  need to handle the string and TeX output.  The
00341 #  underlying type is still an Inerval.
00342 #
00343 package PiecewiseFunction::Interval;
00344 our @ISA = ("Inequalities::Interval");
00345 
00346 sub string {
00347   my $self = shift;  my $equation = shift;
00348   my $x = $self->{varName} || ($self->context->variables->names)[0];
00349   $x = $context->{variables}{$x}{string} if defined $context->{variables}{$x}{string};
00350   $x . ' in ' . $self->demote->string;
00351 }
00352 
00353 sub TeX {
00354   my $self = shift;  my $equation = shift;
00355   my $x = $self->{varName} || ($self->context->variables->names)[0];
00356   $x = $context->{variables}{$x}{TeX} if defined $context->{variables}{$x}{TeX};
00357   $x =~ s/^([^_]+)_?(\d+)$/$1_{$2}/;
00358   $x . '\in ' . $self->demote->TeX;
00359 }
00360 
00361 ##################################################
00362 ##################################################
00363 #
00364 #  This implements the PiecewiseFunction.  It is an unusual mix
00365 #  of a Value object and a Formula object.  It looks like a
00366 #  Formula for the most part, but doesn't have the same internal
00367 #  structure.  Most of the Formula methods have been provided
00368 #  so that eval, substitute, reduce, etc will be applied to all
00369 #  the branches.
00370 #
00371 package PiecewiseFunction::Function;
00372 our @ISA = ('Value', 'Value::Formula');
00373 
00374 #
00375 #  Create the PiecewiseFunction object, with error reporting
00376 #  for problems in the data.
00377 #
00378 #  Usage:  PiecewiseFunction("formula")
00379 #          PiecewiseFunction(I1 => f1, I2 => f2, ... , fn);
00380 #
00381 #  In the first case, the formula is parsed for "if" and "else" values
00382 #  to produce the function.  In the second, the function is given
00383 #  by interval/formula pairs that associate what function to map over
00384 #  interval.  If there is an unpaired formula at the end, it is
00385 #  the "otherwise" formula that will be used whenever the input
00386 #  does not fall into one of the given intervals.
00387 #
00388 #  Note that the intervals above actually can be Interval, Set,
00389 #  or Union objects, not just plain intervals.
00390 #
00391 sub new {
00392   my $self = shift; my $class = ref($self) || $self;
00393   my $context = (Value::isContext($_[0]) ? shift : $self->context);
00394   Value->Error("You must provide at least one Formula for a Piecewise Function") unless scalar(@_);
00395   my $F = shift; $F = [$F,@_] if scalar(@_);
00396   return $F if ref($F) eq $class;
00397   unless (ref($F) eq 'ARRAY') {
00398     $F = $context->Package("Formula")->new($context,$F);
00399     if ($F->{tree}->can("Compute")) {
00400       $F = $F->{tree}->Compute($context);
00401       return $F if ref($F) eq $class;
00402     }
00403     $F = [$F];
00404   }
00405   my $pf = bless {data => [], context => $context, isPiecewiseFunction => 1}, $class;
00406   my $x = ''; $pf->{variables} = {};
00407   while (scalar(@$F) > 1) {
00408     my $I = shift(@$F); my $f = shift(@$F);
00409     $I = $context->Package("Interval")->new($context,$I) unless Value::classMatch($I,"Interval","Set","Union");
00410     $f = $context->Package("Formula")->new($context,$f) unless Value::isFormula($f);
00411     $I->{equation} = $f->{equation} = $pf; ### Transfer equation flag?
00412     push(@{$pf->{data}},[$I,$f]);
00413     $x = $I->{varName} unless $x;
00414     foreach my $v (keys %{$f->{variables}}) {$pf->{variables}{$v} = 1}
00415   }
00416   if (scalar(@$F)) {
00417     $pf->{otherwise} = $context->Package("Formula")->new($context,shift(@$F));
00418     $pf->{otherwise}{equation} = $pf;  ### transfer?
00419     foreach my $v (keys %{$pf->{otherwise}{variables}}) {$pf->{variables}{$v} = 1}
00420   }
00421   $pf->{varName} = ($x || ($context->variables->names)[0]);
00422   $pf->{variables}{$pf->{varName}} = 1;
00423   $pf->check;
00424   return $pf;
00425 }
00426 
00427 #
00428 #  Create a PiecewiseFunction without error checking (so overlapping intervals,
00429 #  incorrect variables, and so on could appear).
00430 #
00431 sub make {
00432   my $self = shift; my $class = ref($self) || $self;
00433   my $context = (Value::isContext($_[0]) ? shift : $self->context);
00434   my $pf = bless {data => [], context => $context, isPiecewiseFunction => 1}, $class;
00435   my $x = '';
00436   while (scalar(@_) > 1) {
00437     my $I = shift; my $f = shift;
00438     $I->{equation} = $f->{equation} = $pf;  ### Transfer equation flag?
00439     $x = $I->{varName} unless $x;
00440     push(@{$pf->{data}},[$I,$f]);
00441     $self->{typeRef} = $f->typeRef unless defined $self->{typeRef};
00442     foreach my $v (keys %{$f->{variables}}) {$pf->{variables}{$v} = 1}
00443   }
00444   if (scalar(@_)) {
00445     $pf->{otherwise} = shift;
00446     $pf->{otherwise}{equation} = $pf;  ### transfer?
00447     foreach my $v (keys %{$f->{otherwise}{variables}}) {$pf->{variables}{$v} = 1}
00448   }
00449   $pf->{varName} = ($x || ($context->variables->names)[0]);
00450   $pf->{variables}{$pf->{varName}} = 1;
00451   return $pf;
00452 }
00453 
00454 #
00455 #  Do the consistency checks for the separate branches.
00456 #
00457 sub check {
00458   my $self = shift;
00459   $self->checkVariable;
00460   $self->checkMultipleValued;
00461   $self->checkTypes;
00462 }
00463 
00464 #
00465 #  Check that all the inequalities are for the same variable.
00466 #
00467 sub checkVariable {
00468   my $self = shift; my $context = $self->context;
00469   my $x = $self->{varName};
00470   foreach my $If (@{$self->{data}}) {
00471     my ($I,$f) = @$If;
00472     $I = $If->[0] = $context->Package("Inequality")->new($context,$I,$x)
00473       unless $I->classMatch("Inequality");
00474     Value->Error("All the intervals must use the same variable") if $I->{varName} ne $x;
00475   }
00476 }
00477 
00478 #
00479 #  Check that no domain intervals overlap.
00480 #
00481 sub checkMultipleValued {
00482   my $self = shift;
00483   my @D = $self->domainUnion->sort->value;
00484   foreach my $i (0..scalar(@D)-2) {
00485     my ($I,$J) = @D[$i,$i+1];
00486     Value->Error("A piecewise function can't have overlapping domain intervals")
00487       if $I->intersects($J);
00488   }
00489 }
00490 
00491 #
00492 #  Check that all the branches return the same type of result.
00493 #
00494 sub checkTypes {
00495   my $self = shift;
00496   foreach my $If (@{$self->{data}}) {$self->checkType($If->[1])}
00497   $self->checkType($self->{otherwise}) if defined $self->{otherwise};
00498 }
00499 
00500 sub checkType {
00501   my $self = shift; my $f = shift;
00502   if (defined $self->{typeRef}) {
00503     Value->Error("All the formulas must produce the same type of answer")
00504       unless Parser::Item::typeMatch($self->{typeRef},$f->typeRef);
00505   } else {$self->{typeRef} = $f->typeRef}
00506 }
00507 
00508 #
00509 #  This is always considered a formula.
00510 #
00511 sub isConstant {0}
00512 
00513 #
00514 #  Look through the branches for the one that contains
00515 #  the variable's value, and evaluate it.  If not in
00516 #  any of the intervals, use the "otherwise" value,
00517 #  or die with no value if there isn't one.
00518 #
00519 sub eval {
00520   my $self = shift;
00521   $self->setValues(@_); my $x = $self->{values}{$self->{varName}}; $self->unsetValues;
00522   foreach my $If (@{$self->{data}}) {
00523     my ($I,$f) = @{$If};
00524     return $f->eval(@_) if $I->contains($x);
00525   }
00526   return $self->{otherwise}->eval(@_) if defined $self->{otherwise};
00527   die "undefined value";
00528 }
00529 
00530 #
00531 #  Reduce each branch individually.
00532 #
00533 sub reduce {
00534   my $self = shift; my @cases = ();
00535   foreach my $If (@{$self->{data}}) {
00536     my ($I,$f) = @{$If};
00537     push(@cases,$I->copy => $f->reduce(@_));
00538   }
00539   push(@cases,$self->{otherwise}->reduce(@_)) if defined $self->{otherwise};
00540   return $self->make(@cases);
00541 }
00542 
00543 #
00544 #  Substitute into each branch individually.
00545 #  If the function's variable is substituted, then
00546 #    if it is a constant, find the branch for that value
00547 #    and substitute into that, otherwise if it is
00548 #    just another variable, replace the variable
00549 #    in the inequalities as well as the formulas.
00550 #  Otherwise, just replace in the formulas.
00551 #
00552 sub substitute {
00553   my $self = shift;
00554   my @cases = (); my $x = $self->{varName};
00555   $self->setValues(@_); my $a = $self->{values}{$x}; $self->unsetValues(@_);
00556   if (defined $a) {
00557     if (!Value::isFormula($a)) {
00558       my $f = $self->getFunctionFor($a);
00559       die "undefined value" unless defined $f;
00560       return $f->substitute(@_);
00561     }
00562     $x = $a->{tree}{name} if $a->{tree}->class eq 'Variable';
00563   }
00564   foreach my $If (@{$self->{data}}) {
00565     my ($I,$f) = @{$If};
00566     $I = $I->copy; if ($x ne $I->{varName}) {$I->{varName} = $x; $I->updateParts}
00567     push(@cases,$I => $f->substitute(@_));
00568   }
00569   push(@cases,$self->{otherwise}->substitute(@_)) if defined $self->{otherwise};
00570   return $self->make(@cases);
00571 }
00572 
00573 
00574 #
00575 #  Return the domain of the function (will be (-inf,inf) if
00576 #  there is an "otherwise" formula.
00577 #
00578 sub domain {
00579   my $self = shift;
00580   return $self->domainR if defined $self->{otherwise};
00581   return $self->domainUnion->reduce;
00582 }
00583 
00584 #
00585 #  The set (-inf,inf).
00586 #
00587 sub domainR {
00588   my $self = shift; my $context = $self->context;
00589   my $Infinity = $context->Package("Infinity")->new($context);
00590   return $context->Package("Interval")->make($context,'(',-$Infinity,$Infinity,')');
00591 }
00592 
00593 #
00594 #  The domain formed by the explicitly given intervals
00595 #  (excludes the "otherwise" portion, if any)
00596 #
00597 sub domainUnion {
00598   my $self = shift; my $context = $self->context;
00599   my @cases = (); foreach my $If (@{$self->{data}}) {push(@cases,$If->[0])}
00600   return $context->Package("Union")->make($context,@cases);
00601 }
00602 
00603 #
00604 #  Creates a copy of the PiecewiseFunction where the "otherwise"
00605 #  formula has been given explicit intervals within the object.
00606 #  (This makes it easier to compare two PiecewiseFormulas
00607 #  interval by interval.)
00608 #
00609 sub noOtherwise {
00610   my $self = (shift)->copy; my $context = $self->context;
00611   return $self unless defined $self->{otherwise};
00612   my $otherwise = $self->domainR - $self->domainUnion->reduce;
00613   return $self if $otherwise->isEmpty;
00614   $otherwise = $context->Package("Union")->new($context,$otherwise) unless $otherwise->type eq 'Union';
00615   foreach my $I ($otherwise->value) {
00616     my $D = $context->Package("Inequality")->new($context,$I,$self->{varName});
00617     push(@{$self->{data}},[$D,$self->{otherwise}]);
00618   }
00619   delete $self->{otherwise};
00620   foreach my $If (@{$self->{data}}) {$If->[0]{equation} = $If->[1]{equation} = $self}
00621   return $self;
00622 }
00623 
00624 #
00625 #  Look up the function for the nth branch (or the "otherwise"
00626 #  function if n is omitted or too big or too small).
00627 #
00628 sub getFunction {
00629   my $self = shift; my $n = shift;
00630   return $self->{otherwise} if !defined $n || $n < 1 || $n > $self->length;
00631   return $self->{data}[$n-1][1];
00632 }
00633 
00634 #
00635 #  Look up the domain for the nth branch (or the "otherwise"
00636 #  domain if n is omitted or too big or too small).
00637 #
00638 sub getDomain {
00639   my $self = shift; my $n = shift;
00640   return $self->Package("Inequality")->new($self->context,
00641     $self->domainR - $self->domainUnion,$self->{varName})
00642        if !defined $n || $n < 1 || $n > $self->length;
00643   return $self->{data}[$n-1][0];
00644 }
00645 
00646 #
00647 #  Get the function for the given value of the variable
00648 #  (or undef if there is none).
00649 #
00650 sub getFunctionFor {
00651   my $self = shift; my $x = shift;
00652   foreach my $If (@{$self->{data}}) {
00653     my ($I,$f) = @$If;
00654     return $f if $I->contains($x);
00655   }
00656   return $self->{otherwise};
00657 }
00658 
00659 #
00660 #  Implements the <=> operator (really only handles equality ir not)
00661 #
00662 sub compare {
00663   my ($l,$r,$flag) = @_; my $self = $l;
00664   my $context = $self->context; my $result;
00665   $r = $context->Package("PiecewiseFunction")->new($context,$r) unless Value::classMatch($r,"PiecewiseFunction");
00666   Value::Error("Formulas from different contexts can't be compared")
00667     unless $l->{context} == $r->{context};
00668   $l = $l->noOtherwise; $r = $r->noOtherwise;
00669   $result = $l->compareDomains($r); return $result if $result;
00670   $result = $l->compareFormulas($r); return $result if $result;
00671   return 0;
00672 }
00673 
00674 #
00675 #  Check that the function domains have the same number of
00676 #  components, and that those components agree, interval by interval.
00677 #
00678 sub compareDomains {
00679   my $self = shift; my $other = shift;
00680   my @D0 = $self->domainUnion->sort->value;
00681   my @D1 = $other->domainUnion->sort->value;
00682   return scalar(@D0) <=> scalar(@D1) unless scalar(@D0) == scalar(@D1);
00683   foreach my $i (0..$#D0) {
00684     my $result = ($D0[$i] <=> $D1[$i]);
00685     return $result if $result;
00686   }
00687   return 0;
00688 }
00689 
00690 #
00691 #  Now that the intervals are known to agree, compare
00692 #  the individual functions on each interval.  Do an
00693 #  appropriate check depending on the type of each
00694 #  branch:  Interval, Set, or Union.
00695 #
00696 sub compareFormulas {
00697   my $self = shift; my $other = shift;
00698   my @D0 = main::PGsort(sub {$_[0][0] < $_[1][0]}, $self->value);
00699   my @D1 = main::PGsort(sub {$_[0][0] < $_[1][0]}, $other->value);
00700   foreach my $i (0..$#D0) {
00701     my ($D,$f0,$f1) = (@{$D0[$i]},$D1[$i][1]);
00702     my $method = "compare".$D->type;
00703     my $result = $self->$method($D,$f0,$f1);
00704     return $result if $result;
00705   }
00706   return 0;
00707 }
00708 
00709 #
00710 #  Use the Interval to determine the limits for use
00711 #  in comparing the two functions.
00712 #
00713 sub compareInterval {
00714   my $self = shift; my ($D,$f0,$f1) = @_;
00715   my ($a,$b) = $D->value; $a = $a->value; $b = $b->value;
00716   return $f0 == $f1 if $D->{leftInfinite} && $D->{rightInfinite};
00717   $a = $b - 2 if $D->{leftInfinite};
00718   $b = $a + 2 if $D->{rightInfinite};
00719   return $f0->with(limits=>[$a,$b]) <=> $f1;
00720 }
00721 
00722 #
00723 #  For a set, check that the functions agree on every point.
00724 #
00725 sub compareSet {
00726   my $self = shift; my ($D,$f0,$f1) = @_;
00727   my $x = $self->{varName};
00728   foreach my $a ($self->value) {
00729     my $result = $f0->eval($x=>$a) <=> $f1->eval($x=>$a);
00730     return $result if $result;
00731   }
00732   return 0;
00733 }
00734 
00735 #
00736 #  For a union, do the appropriate check for
00737 #  each object in the union.
00738 #
00739 sub compareUnion {
00740   my $self = shift; my ($D,$f0,$f1) = @_;
00741   foreach my $S ($self->value) {
00742     my $method = "compare".$S->type;
00743     my $result = $self->$method($D,$f0,$f1);
00744     return $result if $result;
00745   }
00746   return 0;
00747 }
00748 
00749 
00750 #
00751 #  Stringify using newlines at after each "else".
00752 #  (Otherwise the student and correct answer can
00753 #  get unacceptably long.)
00754 #
00755 sub string {
00756   my $self = shift; my @cases = ();
00757   my $period = ($self->{final_period} ? "." : "");
00758   foreach my $If (@{$self->{data}}) {
00759     my ($I,$f) = @{$If};
00760     push(@cases,$f->string." if ".$I->string);
00761   }
00762   push(@cases,$self->{otherwise}->string) if defined $self->{otherwise};
00763   join(" else\n",@cases) . $period;
00764 }
00765 
00766 #
00767 #  TeXify using a "cases" LaTeX environment.
00768 #
00769 sub TeX {
00770   my $self = shift; my @cases = ();
00771   my $period = ($self->{final_period} ? "." : "");
00772   foreach my $If (@{$self->{data}}) {
00773     my ($I,$f) = @{$If};
00774     push(@cases,'\displaystyle{'.$f->TeX."}&\\text{if}\\ ".$I->TeX);
00775   }
00776   if (scalar(@cases)) {
00777     push(@cases,'\displaystyle{'.$self->{otherwise}->TeX.'}&\text{otherwise}') if defined $self->{otherwise};
00778     return '\begin{cases}'.join('\cr'."\n",@cases).$period.'\end{cases}';
00779   } else {
00780     return $self->{otherwise}->TeX;
00781   }
00782 }
00783 
00784 #
00785 #  Create a code segment that returns the correct value depending on which
00786 #  interval contains the variable's value (or an undefined value).
00787 #
00788 sub perl {
00789   my $self = shift; my $x = "\$".$self->{varName};
00790   my @cases = ();
00791   foreach my $If (@{$self->{data}}) {
00792     my ($I,$f) = @{$If};
00793     push(@cases,'return '.$f->perl.' if '.$I->perl.'->contains('.$x.');');
00794   }
00795   if (defined($self->{otherwise})) {push(@cases,'return '.$self->{otherwise}->perl.';')}
00796                               else {push(@cases,'die "undefined value";')}
00797   return join("\n",@cases);
00798 }
00799 
00800 
00801 #
00802 #  Handle the types correctly for error messages and such.
00803 #
00804 sub class {"PiecewiseFunction"}
00805 sub showClass {
00806   my $self = shift;
00807   my $f = $self->{data}[0][1]; $f = $self->{otherwise} unless defined $f;
00808   'a Formula that returns '.Value::showType($f->{tree});
00809 }
00810 
00811 sub type {(shift)->{typeRef}{name}}
00812 sub typeRef {(shift)->{typeRef}}
00813 
00814 #
00815 #  Allow comparison only when the two functions return
00816 #  the same type of result.
00817 #
00818 sub typeMatch {
00819   my $self = shift; my $other = shift; my $ans = shift;
00820   return $self->type eq $other->type;
00821 }
00822 
00823 ##################################################
00824 #
00825 #  Overrides the Formula() command so that if
00826 #  the result is a PiecewiseFunction, it is
00827 #  turned into one automatically.  Conversely,
00828 #  if a PiecewiseFunction is put into Formula(),
00829 #  this will turn it into a Formula.
00830 #
00831 package PiecewiseFunction::Formula;
00832 our @ISA = ('Value::Formula');
00833 
00834 sub new {
00835   my $self = shift; my $f;
00836   if (scalar(@_) == 1 && Value::classMatch($_[0],"PiecewiseFunction")) {
00837     $f = $_[0]->string; $f =~ s/\n/ /g;
00838     $f = $self->Package("Formula")->new($f);
00839   } else {
00840     $f = $self->Package("Formula")->new(@_);
00841     $f = $f->{tree}->Compute if $f->{tree}{canCompute};
00842   }
00843   return $f;
00844 }
